title: Figure

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of oil and chalk on canvas.

credit_line: Gift of Florene May Schoenborn and Samuel A. Marx
publication_history:
“Contemporary Art in the Bay Region—1950,” San Francisco Museum of Art, Magazine of Art (March 1950), p. lxxxx (ill.), as Figure.

Christian Zervos, Pablo Picasso VII (Paris: Cahiers d’Art, 1955), p. 51, no. 118 (ill.), as Figure.

Alfred H. Barr, Jr., Picasso: 75th Anniversary Exhibition, exh. cat. (New York: Museum of Modern Art, 1957), p. 63 (ill.).

Picasso, exh. cat. (Philadelphia: Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1958), p. 19, cat. 116 (ill.).

Paintings in The Art Institute of Chicago, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1961), p. 357.

“Samuel A. Marx 1885–1964,” The Art Institute of Chicago Quarterly 58:1 (1964), p. 4 (ill.).

The School of Paris: Paintings from the Florence May Schoenborn and Samuel A. Marx Collection, exh. cat. (New York: Museum of Modern Art, 1965), p. 26 (ill.)

Yoshiaki Tono, Picasso/Braque, Gendai Sekai Bijutsu Zenshu 7 (Tokyo: Kawade Shobo, 1966), p. 118, pl. 28.

Picasso in Chicago, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1968), p. 32, cat. 31 (ill.).

Sandra Grung, Supplement to Paintings in The Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1971), p. 86.

A. James Speyer and Courtney Graham Donnell, Twentieth Century European Painting (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1980), p. 64, no. 3D7.

Picasso (France: ODA Laser Edition, 1992), p. 49, no. 22074, as Figure.

James N. Wood and Teri J. Edelstein, The Art Institute of Chicago: Twentieth-Century Painting and Sculpture (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 1996), p. 57 (ill.).

The Picasso Project, Picasso’s Paintings, Watercolors, Drawings, and Sculpture: A Comprehensive Illustrated Catalogue 1885–1973, Toward Surrealism 1925–1929 (San Francisco: Alan Wofsy Fine Arts, 1996), p. 91, no. 27–030 (ill), as Head of a Woman.

Michael Fitzgerald and Julia May Boddewyn, Picasso and American Art, exh. cat. (New York: Whitney Museum of American Art, 2006), pp. 367 and 376.

Liz O'Brien, Ultramodern, Samuel Marx: Architecth, Designer, Art Collector (New York? Pointed Leaf Press, 2007), pp. 122-23.

Stephanie D'Alessandro, Picasso and Chicago, exh. cat. (Chicago: The Art Institute of Chicago, 2013), pp. 22, 66-67, pl. 49; 105, cat. 79 (ill.).

T.J. Clark, Picasso and Truth (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2013), p. 201, fig. 5.10.

Enrique Mallen, The On-Line Picasso Project (http://www.tamu.edu/mocl/picasso/), no. 27–08 (ill.), as Tête de femme.

Picasso. Tableaux magiques, exh. cat. (Paris: Musée national Picasso-Paris, 2019), cover (ill.), pp. 26 and 74, cat. 24 (ill.), p. 149.

Marilyn McCully and Michael Raeburn, "L'Artiste-magicien," Picasso. Tableaux magiques, exh. cat. (Paris: Musée national Picasso-Paris, 2019), p. 26.
exhibition_history:
San Francisco Museum of Art, Modern Masterpieces of the Bay Region—15th Anniversary, Jan. 1950, no cat.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Gallery of Art Interpretation: Presenting the Art Institute's Picassos, Sept.–Dec. 1955, no cat.

New York, Museum of Modern Art, Picasso: 75th Anniversary Exhibition, May 22–Sept. 5, 1957; The Art Institute of Chicago, Oct.29–Dec. 8, 1957.

Philadelphia Museum of Art, Picasso, Jan. 8–Feb. 23, 1958, cat. 116.

New York, Museum of Modern Art, The School of Paris: Paintings from the Florence May Schoenborn and Samuel A. Marx Collection, Nov. 1, 1965–Jan. 2, 1966; The Art Institute of Chicago, Feb. 11–Mar. 27, 1966; City Art Museum of St. Louis, Apr. 27–June 13, 1966; Mexico City, Museo de Arte Moderno, July 2–Aug. 7, 1966; San Francisco, Museum of Art, Sept. 2–Oct. 2, 1966.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Picasso in Chicago, Feb. 3–Mar. 31, 1968, cat. 31.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Picasso and Chicago, Feb. 20–May 12, 2013, cat. 79.

Fort Worth, Kimbell Art Museum, The Age of Picasso and Matisse: Modern Masters from the Art Institute of Chicago, Oct. 6, 2013–Feb. 16, 2014, no cat. no. 

Paris, Musée national Picasso-Paris, Picasso. Tableaux magiques, Oct. 1, 2019–Feb. 23, 2020, cat. 24.
provenance_text: The artist; sold to Gordon Onslow-Ford (1912-2003) with the aid of André Breton (1896-1966), Paris, 1940; transferred from the studio of Pablo Picasso to Gordon Onslow-Ford, San Francisco, 1948 (physical transfer of object delayed) [letter from Gordon Onslow-Ford of April 15, 1951 in curatorial file]; sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1951.
